page.title: 11BROXBOURNE/BRICKENDON ROADS
page.content: Opened in l973, the Al0 road was built to relieve the old road through the Broxbourne district and is part of the main London/Cambridge route. It has been skilfully screened by trees and banks & a tunnel has been provided for badgers - rather apt as the derivation of Broxbourne is "badger's stream" or possibly "stream of a man named Brocc" Originally made of cement the north- bound carriageway has now been resurfaced with tarmac & the south- bound is due to be repaired as soon as finance is available. Roads to the west of the Al0, across to Brickendon, are in reasonable condition although narrow & mostly kerbless. They are well used during some parts of the day & at weekends horse riders add to the traffic. There is an interchange at Hoddesdon for access to the town and district.
